abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that the project
            has demonstrated that the demand-driven approach, as an
            alternative to the traditional supply-driven service
            delivery, works quite successfully. Making the communities
            participate fully in the decision-making process and in
            contributing cash and labor have enabled them to gain a
            sense of ownership of their infrastructure schemes. The
            project has also demonstrated to the government that reform
            is possible, and that it pays to try innovative ways of
            delivering infrastructure services. The project's
            experience highlights the need to have effective planning
            and monitoring and evaluation mechanisms, for example, with
            an efficient Management Information System (MIS) system in
            place from the beginning of a project. To scale up the
            demand-driven approach to service delivery, it is important
            that the implementing entity (such as the Fund Board) does
            not become dependent on IDA/donor financing. Although the
            project has enabled the communities to own and operate their
            infrastructure schemes without any significant assistance
            from the sector institutions or the local government
            agencies, the need to ensure follow-up support to
            communities and NGOs in case of natural calamities, for
            example, remains crucial. Given the Support
            Organization's (Sos) high involvement in mobilizing and
            guiding the communities, it is crucial to pay strong
            attention to the selection and training of the SOs.
